job_description: HPD Research and Evaluation conducts rigorous statistical analyses, large scale surveys, and evaluations of Agency programming to support new knowledge and help refine practices related to the housing stock, population, and communities we serve. R&E leverages resources within and across the traditional divides of government and academia to facilitate discussion and establish an innovative and holistic approach to housing policy research. Our research produces methodologically sound findings to shape effective policy and programming, and promote data-driven policymaking in New York City and beyond.  The Senior Researcher will report to the agencyâ€™s Acting Assistant Commissioner of Research & Evaluation, who resides in the Office of the Chief of Staff. The Senior Researcher will work with the Assistant Commissioner to develop and facilitate the agencyâ€™s research agenda, as well as design and execute program evaluations and various statistical analyses in support of the teamâ€™s ongoing projects and the needs of the Commissioner. The Senior Researcher will work closely with the team to define new projects, develop analytic strategies that serve the needs of the agency, execute program evaluations and policy studies, mentor and support junior researchers and RAs, and present findings to academic and policymaking audiences. The Researcher will help to develop the teamâ€™s agenda and participate in high level meetings with the Agency and City Hall in order to facilitate and support the Cityâ€™s evidence-based policymaking practices. Furthermore, s/he will work closely with the Office of Neighborhood Strategies (ONS) to provide analytic support for this important new branch of HPD.   Specific duties of the Senior Researcher include working with internal, senior-level stakeholders to identify and prioritize programs of interest for evaluation, developing preliminary research proposals for high priority areas of interest, writing funding proposals to philanthropic and federal agencies, and conducting analyses as appropriate. The Senior Researcher will be responsible for compiling, presenting, and disseminating findings, as well as designing and implementing data management procedures in order to help provide a framework for future research.   The Senior Researcher will be expected to work directly with stakeholders at all levels of the agency.  As such, teamwork and relationship building will be essential components of the role. The ideal candidate is one who is able to learn independently, think and work collaboratively, practice strong research ethics, and exhibit a commitment to conducting research with the goal of improving public policy.  This position requires the following education, experience and skills: Doctoral Degree in Public Policy, Urban Planning, Public Administration, Sociology, Economics or other related field; 2-3 years of experience conducting research, including the identification of outcome measures, ensuring reliability and validity, sampling, primary and secondary data collection, data management and methods of analysis; OR Masters degree in a related field  AND 5 years of experience;   Experience managing and manipulating administrative data;  Literacy in at least one of the following sets of statistical methods: econometrics, spatial analysis, hierarchical modeling and/or survey analysis; Fluency in multivariate (OLS) regression and categorical data analysis, as well as assumptions underlying such methods; Mastery of statistical software such as Stata or SAS; Ability to communicate complex statistical data and concepts to a lay audience while maintaining the integrity of oneâ€™s findings; Proven desire to learn by doing and work hard to ensure the highest quality work product; Energetic, pro-active, independent, and intellectually-curious; Strong written and oral communications skills.

EAO is tasked with reviewing and approving payments and change orders for construction and construction-related services for accuracy and compliance with City requirements. The Engineering Auditor will focus on reviews related to energy efficiency projects and initiatives in order to assist the Agency in meeting its objectives under the Mayorâ€™s One City: Built to Last Plan. job_description: The Division of Economic and Financial Opportunity is committed to encouraging a competitive and diverse New York City business environment by promoting the growth and success of small businesses, with special emphasis on historically underserved groups, and ensuring their meaningful participation in the government procurement process.  The goals of the division are to increase and retain the number of certified minority and women-owned business enterprises (M/WBE); increase the number of M/WBEs winning government contacts, and increase overall M/WBE participation in private and public sector contracting.  Reporting to the Director of Buyer Services, the Compliance Officer will provide support and related services to Agency Buyers and NYC certified M/WBE/EBE firms to ensure compliance with Local Law 1 provisions.   Specific Responsibilities:  â€¢Review and distribute regular agency performance reports, provide guidance to agencies by researching and analyzing City agency contract data, interpreting data trends, and identifying areas of opportunity to increase M/WBEs utilization;   â€¢Conduct periodic meetings with agency representatives to discuss progress toward meeting goals, make recommendations, and track the implementation of recommendations;  â€¢Prepare and distribute annual Performance Improvement Plans to agencies that do not meet a minimum required utilization goal.  Host follow-up meetings with each agency to discuss performance and determine initiatives agency should undertake to improve utilization;  â€¢Manage the Citywide Contract Audit to ensure agency compliance with meeting M/WBE goals as prescribed in Local Law 1.  Oversee process starting from the contracting of auditing services through City agency implementation of audit recommendations;  â€¢Coordinate with SBS Audit and Legal Units to collect information requested during M/WBE/LBE/EBE audits and FOIL requests;   â€¢Coordinate with MOCS and/or DOI on any M/WBE vendor compliance issues that may impact certification eligibility;  â€¢Assist with special projects as needed.

job_description: New York Cityâ€™s Department of Housing Preservation and Development (HPD) seeks a dynamic candidate for an Analyst position in the Division of Strategic Planning (DSP), housed within the Office of Strategy, Research, and Communications.  DSP is responsible for shaping and implementing agency priority projects that address the most critical housing policy issues facing HPD and the City as a whole, to help meet the ambitious goals of the Housing New York plan. DSP is also responsible for carrying out projects which address and improve upon the agencyâ€™s operations, often crossing divisional lines within the agency, and coordinating with external city agencies and non-profit partners.   JOB DESCRIPTION Reporting to the Assistant Commissioner of Strategic Planning, the Analyst must be able to work independently and collaboratively with other teams across the agency, including senior staff, to identify, clarify, analyze, and resolve complex issues critical to HPDâ€™s strategic policy and operating success.  The ideal candidate will be enterprising, resourceful, organized and results-oriented. The candidate will have an ability to work with large data sets and translate findings for senior HPD staff to make efficient, effective, and equitable policy decisions.  The person who fulfills this role will apply his or her analytic and problem-solving skills in a proactive, collaborative, and strategic way. The candidate should possess strong financial analysis skills and, preferably, a thorough understanding of real estate economics.  In addition, the candidate should feel comfortable working in a small group within a large organization, setting direction while working flexibly within existing constraints and shifting priority projects.   The candidate will be expected to work directly with stakeholders at all levels of the agency. As such, teamwork, diplomacy, and consensus building are essential components of the Analystâ€™s work.  The candidate should also be able to operate independently, carry out assignments in a timely fashion, and demonstrate sound judgment in decision-making.

business_title_phonetic: Senior Preparedness Evaluator, Bureau of Agency Preparedness and Response
job_description: The New York City Department of Health and Mental Hygiene (DOHMH), an agency recognized worldwide for being a leader in public health and at the forefront of cutting-edge public health emergency planning initiatives, seeks a dynamic professional with excellent communication, project management, and facilitation skills, to serve as a Senior Preparedness Evaluator within the Agencyâ€™s Office of Emergency Preparedness and Response (OEPR).   OEPR is comprised of four bureaus, specifically the Bureau of Agency Preparedness and Response, the Bureau of Grant Management and Administration, the Bureau of Healthcare System Readiness, and the Bureau of Policy, Community Resilience and Response. This position is situated in the Bureau of Agency Preparedness and Response, Evaluation Unit.  The Evaluation Unit investigates, documents, and tracks DOHMH operational improvements from the Agencyâ€™s public health emergency responses and preparedness exercises. Using robust evaluation methods, the Evaluation Unit is responsible for designing and collecting qualitative and quantitative data for its After-Action Reports and Improvement Plans, and uses these to track agency corrective actions to completion. Specifically, the Unit works closely with the Exercises and Training Unit to develop and evaluate complex functional preparedness exercises; with the Grants Unit to design unique preparedness performance measures; and, in partnership with internal and external partners, design and implementation derived from rigorous disaster research. The Unit also provides broader support to the Office that includes operational review, project assessment and design, performance measure development, preparedness research, and real-time data collection.  JOB DESCRIPTION: The Senior Preparedness Evaluator will join the Evaluation Unit within OEPR. The position will have the following primary duties, but not limited to: o	Work closely with the Exercise and Training Unit, exercise planning team members and exercise directors to (i) plan the annual Training and Exercise calendar for the agency, based on current / developing plans, After Action Reports, and corrective actions, and (ii) lead the design and execution for all tabletop, functional, and full scale exercises conducted by the Office. o	Coordinate and manage production and content of all After Action Reports and summaries for exercises and real events, including their development, review, synthesis, editing, distribution and storage. This includes working with subject matter experts and vendors to ensure documentation is useful to multiple stakeholders. o	Facilitate and lead evaluator trainings, hotwashes (rapid focus groups), and After Action Conferences when needed. o	Oversee and manage the reporting functions of the Corrective Action Retrospective Database (CARD) to comprehensively track agency corrective actions and compile reporting requirements; this responsibility includes providing ongoing training and support to agency wide coordinators who use the system, and exploring methods to analyze corrective actions as a measure of performance o	Conduct ad-hoc syntheses of qualitative data to inform planning, training, and programmatic efforts;  o	Be familiar with and understand the FEMAâ€™s Homeland Security Exercise and Evaluation Program (HSEEP) and the National Incident Management System (ICS);   o	Provide support to operational research projects, and other OEPR priorities, as needed; o	Provide needed response during emergency periods.

job_description: The Division of Youth and Family Justice (DYFJ) is responsible for oversight and management of secure and non-secure detention services for juveniles awaiting disposition in family and supreme courts. DYFJ also oversees a network of community-based prevention, alternative to detention, and alternative to placement programs for youth involved in, or at risk for involvement in, the Juvenile Justice system. Further, DYFJ oversees a wide network of providers throughout the five boroughs that operate Non-Secure Placement sites for youth who are adjudicated delinquent and are placed by the New York City Family Court. That network will soon expand to include youth in Limited Secure Settings.     Under general direction of the DYFJ Senior Advisor for Juvenile Justice Clinical Services, the Senior Analyst will provide direct ongoing operational assistance to the Intake and Assessment unit process for youth entering placement under Close to Home.  Responsibilities will include:    â€¢	In collaboration with DYFJ leadership, coordinate efforts to implement and monitor consistent, integrated, culturally competent service delivery models for mental health in Close to Home and Detention;   â€¢	Work closely with DYFJ program leadership to design, build, and implement appropriate assessment, classification and program models in Close to Home and Detention that are responsive to the social, behavioral, and mental health needs and issues of youth;  â€¢	Travel to both non-secure and secure detention facilities, as well as Close to Home facilities to conduct interviews with youth and families, and to communities to speak with family members when schedules allow to support DYFJ quality improvement efforts;  â€¢	Coordinate and meet regularly with contracted-ACS juvenile justice and psychiatry and mental health services providers, evidence-based program developers, and consultants to discuss trends, disseminate information, and follow up on specific cases, problematic referrals, or policies;  â€¢	Effectively track, record, and use data, research, and evidence-based methods  to inform policy and program development decisions;  â€¢	Actively participate in the Divisionâ€™s efforts to build and sustain mutually beneficial relationships with City and State agencies including DOHMH and NYSOMH and private institutions in an effort to leverage resources, improve service delivery, and coordinate services for juvenile justice involved youth and families;  â€¢	Work inter-divisionally to develop, enhance, research, and coordinate curricula and  training for DYFJ staff  around specific clinical, and programmatic issues related to juvenile justice including adolescent development, mental health, LGBTQ, family engagement, substance abuse, trauma, and case management; and  identify resources that promote and enhance staff development;  â€¢	Provide consultation for and troubleshoot with DYFJ staff, providers and advocacy groups on a host of issues related to the clinical care of individual youth throughout the juvenile justice continuum;  â€¢	Coordinate the provision of conferences and/or service plan meetings with relevant parties when necessary.
